text:
Hello, and welcome to a demo of the AWS
Transfer Family for SFTP, FTPS, and FTP.

The AWS Transfer Family provides fully
managed support to enable transfer of files

over SFTP, FTPS and FTP
into and out of Amazon S3.

The AWS Transfer Family helps you seamlessly
    migrate your file transfer workloads to AWS

without impacting your end users
    and application integrations.

And, getting started is easy - there is no
infrastructure to buy, setup, or maintain.
Let's take a look into how it works.

AWS Transfer Family provides a fully-managed
  endpoint for file transfers into and out of S3.

IAM roles are used to grant access to S3 buckets
     from file transfer clients in a secure way.

Users also have the option to use Route 53 to migrate
    an existing file transfer hostname for use in AWS.

Today, the AWS Transfer Family supports
 3 commonly used file transfer protocols.

These are Secure File Transfer Protocol
or SFTP which is file transfer over SSH,

File Transfer Protocol over SSL or FTPS
which is FTP over a TLS-encrypted channel,
and plain File Transfer Protocol or FTP.

SFTP and FTPS protocols can be setup
to be accessible from the public internet,

while using FTP is limited to be only accessible
   from inside a VPC through VPC endpoints.
In the remainder of this video

Iâ€™ll walk through how the AWS Transfer Family can
be used with each of the three supported protocols.

For the first part of the demo, I'll demonstrate creating an
 endpoint which will be capable of both SFTP and FTPS
and show accessing it over the public internet.
In the second part I'll create an FTP endpoint
and demo accessing it from within a VPC.
Let's jump in.

Here we are in the console for
  the AWS Transfer Family.

This is the first part of the
demo where I'll create a server

for SFTP and FTPS which can
be accessed over the internet.

Note that in these demos I
 am creating new servers

however this same flow could be
used to modify an existing server

such as adding the FTPS protocol
    to an existing SFTP server.

To get started, I'll click
  on "Create server."

At this point I'm given the choice for which file
transfer protocols I want to enable on this endpoint.

For this part of the demo,
I'll select SFTP and FTPS.

Because I selected FTPS I'll need to specify
  a certificate in AWS Certificate Manager

that will be used as the server
certificate for TLS connections.

I'll select an existing one,
and then click on, "next".

At this point I have the choice of how I
want to authenticate users to this endpoint.

Let's take a second and
 talk about the options.

"Service Managed" means users will be created
and managed within the AWS Transfer service.

I won't be able to choose this option in this
demo as I have selected to enable FTPS.

"Custom" means setting up a
custom authorizer endpoint.
This means an API Gateway endpoint

which is called by AWS Transfer to authenticate
   users when they connect to the endpoint.

This option is typically used for integrating with an existing identity
      provider outside of AWS Transfer or even outside of AWS.

I will provide the API Gateway
  endpoint as well as a role

which will allow AWS Transfer to call this
  endpoint when authenticating users.
I'll click, "next".

Now I have the choice to host my endpoint
     publicly or place it within my VPC.

Public means a publicly accessible
endpoint that is not inside your VPC.

Because of this, you can't use
   security groups around it.

Choosing to host in a VPC means an
endpoint that uses ENIs in your VPC,

and depending on the protocol, you can
have an elastic IP directly attached to it.

This helps you keep EIPs
static for your end users

and because it is in VPC also
enables you to use Security Groups

to restrict access to only your
 client's source IP addresses.

Since I selected FTPS I won't
    be able to choose public.

I'll go back to VPC and then
choose to make it "internet facing".

At this point I could also choose
 to use an existing hostname.

I'm going to skip this in this demo but
here are the options that are available.
I'll then select an existing VPC.
This brings up the list of subnets in the VPC.

I'll select us-east-1a
and 1b availability zones

and then I'll select the public
    subnet in each zone.

I am also choosing to associate
   an elastic IP in each subnet.
I'll click on, "Next".

I'll select a role which will allow AWS
Transfer to write logs to CloudWatch Logs.

For this demo I'll skip over, "Server Host Key",
and "Tags" and click, "Next" to go to the next step.

This page shows a summary
   of what will be created.

I review, and then click
 on, "Create server".

Now I'll just jump to the point
of the server being, online.

Now that the server is
online, let's test it out.

First I'll show that I can test the custom
   authorizer right from the console.
If I click on Test from the Actions menu

I can put in my user's
username and password.

When I click on, "Test", I can see the
response returned from the authorizer.
A 200 is a successful authentication,

and returned in the response is the IAM role
which AWS Transfer should apply to this session.

This is how file transfer users are given
 access to buckets and objects in S3.

I won't go dive into IAM right now but
here is the policy attached to that role.

It allows listing this S3 bucket as well as
granting access to objects in that bucket.

Check the documentation as there there are
many options to further scope down policies

and also the ability to create virtual
directory structures for your users.

Now let's look at the
objects in that S3 bucket.

There are 3 text files
named Test1, 2, and 3.

If I click on one of the files
and go to the S3 Select tab...

I can see a preview of the file contents.
         It's just a one line text file.

I want to call out one more
thing before testing this out.

These are the current inbound rules in my security
group for the VPC in which I deployed the server.

I need to allow inbound
connections on port 22
as this is the SSH port used by SFTP.

I also need to allow inbound connections
on port 21 for the FTP control channel

as well as this ephemeral port
range for the FTP data channel.

Be sure to check the documentation
            to be sure of the port

ranges you'll need to allow for the
protocols you need to support.
Now I'll test using SFTP.

I'm doing this from my local machine over
the public internet using the FileZilla client.

I have already added my SSH
public key to the custom authorizer
so I should be authorized to connect.

Here is the endpoint I just created.
       I'll click on, connect...

The status window shows a successful connection
        and a successful listing of the bucket.

The file viewer window
shows the three text files.

At this point I could download
any of these or upload new files.
Now I'll disconnect and try FTPS.

This is the same endpoint but
using the FTP protocol and port.
and also set to use TLS.

In this case I'm authenticating
using username and password
versus a private key in the SFTP case.

The status window again
shows a successful connection...

and the same 3 files
are shown in the listing.

For the second part of the demo,
I'll show creating an FTP endpoint.

Note that an FTP endpoint without TLS
   can only be created inside a VPC

and can only be accessed
  through VPC endpoints.

I'll start again by clicking,
       Create server.

In this case I'll only select FTP
  in the protocol selections.
I'll click, next.

I'll use the same custom authorizer and the
  same role as in the previous example.
Click, next.

The only options I'll be allowed to select with
 FTP are inside a VPC and Internal access.

I'll select the same VPC
 and the same subnets.
Click on, next again.

I'll use the same logging role
as as the previous example
and click, next.

I'll do a quick review and
then click, Create server.

Again I'll jump to the point
where the server is, online.

Now that the FTP endpoint is
online we can give it a test as well.

I'll do that by first jumping
onto a bastion host in the VPC.

I'll then use a command line
   FTP client to connect.
Notice that the host name is a VPC endpoint.
Again, I'll put in my user's password.

Now, I'll issue an ls command
   to list the available files.

And here are the same
 three files as before.

Just to show we can also do something
  interesting with the files, I'll get one.
If I exit the FTP client I can cat the file
and see the same line of text we saw in S3.

To recap, this video showed how easy
it is to get started using AWS Transfer

for SFTP, FTPS, and FTP to transfer
  files into and out of Amazon S3.

The AWS Transfer Family can be used for
  use cases such as building data lakes,

integrations with existing systems
   which rely on file transfers,
and any other file transfer workload.
Thanks for your time.
I hope you learned more about the AWS Transfer Family.
